33555805.review:
The Steam store is oversaturated with low effort 2D retro platformers.   So when launching this game, I expected just another forgettable entry.

Tales From Space: Mutant Blobs Attack shares almostnone of the low effort, weak attributes of so much indy shovelware that we see today.  Instead, we get an admirable and fun game.

Support for 4K! Keyboard support!  Non-janky controls! But most importantly, instead of another Mario clone, we get what Spores first stage blended with a 2D puzzle platformer.  

Controlling the blob is a lot of fun as you hoover up various objects, which in turn makes you grow big enough to surpass various obstacles.    The look and feel of the game is very well polished - most low effort indy games lack this polish and janky controls ruin the experience.  No so here. 

Only two real criticisms for this - the TV screen overlay is distracting, while it adds to the aesthetic, after a while it's just in the way of a clear sceen.   Secondly the choice of controls is a bit off - the apostrophe key for the attack?  Doesn't work well.   Customisable controls would go a long way, but the quality of the game experience overall lets us gloss over this.  

If you have to play a 2D platformer, this is one of the better examples.

31403987.review:
[h1]Blob..Blob..Blob distrugge![/h1]
Cosa succederebbe se un malvagio blob riuscisse ad uscire dalla sua prigionia e, inglobando di tutto e di più all'interno del proprio corpo, riuscisse a conquistare il mondo? A questa domanda cercano di dare una risposta i ragazzi della Drinkbox Studios con Tales From Space: Mutant Blobs Attack. Sequel di un titolo rilasciato in esclusiva su PS3, Mutant Blobs Attack riprende completamente il sistema di gioco del precedente capitolo cercando di svecchiarlo e di renderlo più appetibile al grande pubblico.

[h1]Trama[/h1]
La trama del titolo è molto semplice: un blob rinchiuso all'interno di un laboratorio, riesce ad uscire. Questo libera tutti i suoi "fratelli" dando inizio alla conquista del mondo che si concluderà solo quando riuscirà ad inglobare al suo interno non solo la Terra ma l'intero Sistema Solare. 

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Il gioco presenta un gameplay a scorrimento sia orizzontale che verticale che si andranno ad alternare in base alla conformazione della mappa in cui ci muoveremo. Il gioco è suddiviso in 5 macrozone: College, Città, Luna, Terre Desolate, Base Militare e Metropoli le quali a loro volta si dividono in 4/5 livelli più un livello bonus che si sblocca con il progredire della storia. Il nostro blob dovrà farsi largo tra le varie mappe del gioco inglobando al suo interno sempre più oggetti al fine di aumentare la sua massa e quindi poter ingurgitare oggetti sempre più grandi. Le ambientazioni sono ben caratterizzate e ognuna presenta delle caratteristiche particolari in base alla zona in cui ci si trova. Il blob avrà a disposizione delle "capacità speciali" (che si sbloccheranno avanzando nel gioco) che gli permetteranno di superare i vari ostacoli che incontrerà nel suo cammino: potrà sfruttare il magnetismo per attaccarsi ad alcune superifci oppure utilizzare la telepatia per spostare a suo piacimento oggetti che gli permetteranno di avanzare nella sua conquista del Mondo. 
All'interno del livello saranno nascosti due "amici" del blob e al termine del livello verrà dato al giocatore un punteggio che varia in base al numero di oggetti inglobati, il tempo impiegato per completare il livello e il numero di "amici" ritrovati; in base al punteggio ottenuto si potrà ottenere o una medaglia d'argento o una oro. 
Il gioco permette l'utilizzo della tastiera e del muose per giocare tuttavia io ho preferito l'utilizzo del controller in quanto i tasti predefiniti del tastiera rendevano il gioco più complicato e meno reattivo nel caso di enigmi che dovevano essere risolti in velocità. 
Divertente è il fatto che si è cercato di dargli un tocco da Z Movie ed all'interno dell'ambiente di gioco troveremo una quantità spropositata di rimandi ad altri giochi, oggetti o fenomeni della cultura pop degli ultimi anni. 
Al termine dei vari capitoli, all'inizio del gioco e alla fine del gioco vi saranno delle cutscene, tuttavia non porteranno grandi spiegazioni alla già semplice trama.
Dal punto di vista della difficoltà il gioco è semplice, tuttavia in alcuni punti può risultare davvero molto frustrante sia a causa della lentezza del blob sia a causa dei comandi poco reattivi che, se in situazioni più tranquille lavorano bene, nelle situazioni più concitate possono portare ad errori e quindi ad eventuali morti. 

[h1]Punti Negativi[/h1]
Il gioco è molto, davvero troppo corto: se non si tende ad ottenere il 100% degli obiettivi si può completare in meno di 2 ore altrimenti, completaro al 100% richiederà solamente 6 ore le quali comprendono eventuali morti o tentativi di ottenere la medaglia d'oro in alcuni livelli. 
Essendo un porting da PS Vita, i comandi non sono molto reattivi, soprattutto quello del salto, e molto spesso ci si troverà a rifare lo stesso punto più di una volta proprio a causa di questa lentezza nella risposta dei comandi. Parlando sempre dei comandi, ho trovato davvero molto scomodo il fatto di utilizzare la telepatia attraverso gli stick analogici poichè molto spesso mi ritrovavo a fare azioni completamente differenti rispetto a quello che in effetti bisognava fare. Questo mi ha portato ad utilizzare il mouse per usare l'abilità, tuttavia anche in questo caso l'ho trovato un metodo molto scomodo in quanto dovevo togliere le mani dal controller per utilizzare il mouse. In questo caso si vede benissimo che è un porting in quanto, questo tipo di azioni, veniva fatto attraverso il touchscreen della PSVita e quindi le azioni potevano essere svolte in maniera più intuitiva.
Un altro punto negativo è sicuramente la musica: ascoltando con attenzione si potrà notare come le tracce che compongono la colonna sonora saranno sempre le stesse e se, in un primo momento possono risultare piacevoli, alla lunga diventano molto monotone e si preferisce mutare il gioco per poter giocare con più calma. 

[h1]Conclusione[/h1]
Tales From Space: Mutant Blobs Attack è un ottimo platform che sfortunatamente soffre di problemi legati all'input dei comandi che risultano poco reattivi e quindi, in un gioco dove la reattività la fa da padrona, potrebbe causa non pochi problemi a coloro che si approcciano al titolo. Tuttavia consiglio di acquistarlo, possibilmente sfruttando i saldi, poichè è un gioco poco longevo che si presta molto ad essere giocato nei ritagli di tempo.

27046559.review:
Tales From Space: Mutant Blobs Attack is a physics-based platformer, with a bit of Katamari Damacy thrown in for good measure, about a space-blob that escapes from a lab, goes on a journey to rescue its friends, and consume the entire planet in the process.

Through a series of a couple dozen levels and a smattering of dialog-free cutscenes, Mutant Blobs Attack tells the story of a blob out for revenge against, well, everything for imprisoning it and all its blob friends and conducting horrible experiments on them. The military tries to stop or destroy the blob, but what fun would the game be if they pulled that off?

While the story is rudimentary at best, Mutant Blobs Attack manages to create a fun, light-hearted, but still slightly dark-comedic atmosphere. The backgrounds of levels are full of references to other games, movies, and internet memes. Some work better than others, but they’re trying to create a humorous tone in a game where a silent, gelatinous protagonist attempts to devour every living thing on earth. The fact that they did it without being too morbid is something of a success in and of itself.

Like any good platformer, it features a couple of collectible types: blue dots that really only affect the end of level score, and the afore-mentioned blob friends. The other blobs, two per level, are often hidden away or behind some nasty trap, making them a bit tougher to collect. 

You are never held back for not collecting enough dots, or missing any of the blobs, but they bring a nice little challenge and some replayability to the game.

The two main mechanics besides basic platforming in the game are size and magnets.

Your blob will absorb office supplies, garbage, food or whatever else it comes across, increasing its size and allowing it to get over or through larger and larger obstacles. It’s very similar to the early part of Katamari Damacy stages, where you really aren’t worried about the final size of the ball, but more about how to get big enough to absorb whatever obstacle is keeping you holed up. 

It works well for Mutant Blobs Attack, and while your starting size adjusts from level to level for… story reasons, it does a good job of matching the feel of the level. Not that realism is the primary goal here, but it would feel a little weird sneaking around a lab, trying to escape unnoticed as a four-foot tall, spike-covered blob. The later levels featuring the blob taking on the military and townsfolk running in terror are a real treat, and a fun way to wrap up the game.

There are also zero gravity segments where the blob can shoot a jet of fire out of… wherever blobs shoot jets of fire, in order to maneuver around. These sections still revolve around absorbing junk and avoiding lasers and other platformer-standard traps, but break up the pace a bit. A nice touch.

The other big mechanic I mentioned earlier centers around the blob’s magnetic abilities. Fairly early in the game it gains the abilities of an electromagnet of sorts, either drawing itself toward or repelling itself from certain metallic objects, which are always conveniently glowing purple. It works well and has you looking at all four edges of the level for how to get where you need to go, as opposed to simply jumping from ledge to ledge.

This game started life as a launch title for the Vita, but it doesn't suffer for it. Many launch titles feel rushed and awkward, but Tales From Space: Mutant Blobs Attack manages to feel comfortable in its own skin. Everything just… works. The developers knew exactly the game they wanted to make, and executed that plan exceptionally well.

Tales from Space: Mutant Blobs Attack is a very fun and exciting game. I not managed to stop playing!

 	You incarnate a blob mutant who wants to take revenge on humanity. Your goal is to eat everything in its path. The levels are progressive and clearly demonstrate how the Blob grew. At each stage it is a little higher. 

The art of the game and a lot of fun and fitting to the theme comedy / fiction '40 ages. The animations are very fun and also remind us that new flash style that dominates some cartoons today. The design is economical but very well spent. The background is a show itself: there are many references and jokes with famous games of all ways. I laugh many times. It’s a game that makes you smile! There are also references to classic movies like King Kong and Godzilla. 

The sound of the game is based on animated effects and fit very well into the design. The songs are very appropriate and remind us of the films of the 40/50/60, and those movies gremlins.
The gameplay is very well balanced and the mechanics are appropriate and varied. Some stages have vision aerial, other side vision, there are times when there is no gravity and movements are like jets of a space ship or bus. The levels are like puzzles and you have to solve to progress. There are little blobs that you have to catch, your friends. 

In short, it is a platform game and you have to play it. I think, "How I had not played this game yet?" Perhaps the only fault of this game is to be short. It could be longer.

24958971.review:
Very nice casual platformer! 

It's more old-school, collect-a-ton, like Super Mario, rather than the more modern precision platformers like Super Meat Boy. So, even if you don't really like how tough most platformers are, this one you can certainly enjoy.

I've never played Katamari Damacy, but the idea is clearly similar. More recently, perhaps Agar.io. Also, Gish!
The physics were absolutely nailed, as the character you control really feels like a blob. Very fun to just play around, trying to collect everything.

The level variety is fairly high, with different sections, some timed, some more puzzle oriented (although there is very light puzzling only), etc. The levels are replete with references to other games through alien-related puns.

The graphic style reminds me a lot of old cartoons, and the music fits the silly, old sci-fi vibe very well too.



If you're into leaderboard climbing, each level counts pretty much everything you do, from collectibles to time spent to count your score, so that may be up your alley. I'm not sure how much better the levels would seem with a 100% speedrun mindset, but many of the orbs' arrangements do seem to have an optimal path. So yeah, if mastering physics is your thing, I'd doubly recommend this!



A very fun diversion, if nothing else! If you enjoy more casual platformers, give it a go. It's fairly short, though, as I've finished (with about 90-95% of the collectibles and medals, etc.?) in 3.7 hours.

Very pleasant little platformer. Clocks in on the short side (2-3 hours) if you're just going for game completion, but I imagine you could add on an extra hour doing extra levels and collecting all the blob friends, and if you feel competitive then they have online leaderboards for high scores.

It's basically 2D Katamari Damacy for most of the game except with telekinesis/magnetism puzzles. Catchy music, cute character designs (who knew a killer blob could be so adorable?) and a nice mix of platforming styles that keep the game from getting stale.

Only real complaints are that the game has a few odd little bugs and crashed on me twice in the middle of a level, but other than that it's a pleasant little romp.

22367013.review:
Revenge is a dish best served cold and gelatinous which is why it's so satisfying to roll over everything that has mistreated the titular mutant blob, growing with each new acquisition like a sentient snowball. Conquering an area is followed by a little newscast vignette, showing those yet to be consumed in increasing stages of panic. Tales from Space: Mutant Blobs Attack creates the feeling of playing an old horror movie complete with dust-cracked edges (just like the CRTV you'd have to watch it on). The bonus levels delve further into this 'blast from the past' aesthetic by mimicking older game experiences. The change of play style that the bonus levels offer is also a welcome change of pace from the series of similar set pieces positioned around the very basic goal of growing larger and moving to the right. 
The game has a keyboard and mouse control scheme that is more than functional, but clearly it was designed around a console as a controller offers greater precision. Oddly enough, there is still one mechanic that the mouse served better for which makes the ability to switch between the two control schemes on a whim an absolute boon. The point system is similarly flexible as it presents an incentive to be meticulous and thus makes things more difficult without punishing players that choose to take an easier way out. The 'beat my high score' mentality this creates gives the short game some much needed replayability.

24 livelli (+ un paio bonus) che si finiscono abbastanza in fretta, e la longevità è forse l'unica piccola pecca di questo gioco, ma che non rovina affatto l'ottimo risultato finale.

Ah, this game, one of my first games on steam, but, nostalgia won't interfere with an honest review.
Tales From Space...yeah, I'm not gonna say the whole title, I'll just use TFS, is a platformer game made by DrinkBoxStudios, in it you control a Blob, who, after seeing the other blobs experimented on, escapes and decides to absorb everything.

One of the interesting mechanics of this game is your size, to progress, you need to be large enough to eat corks blocking your path, you do this by absorbing objects that you CAN absorb at your current size, and this may let you become large enough to absorb bigger objects. This setup sometimes encourages you to explore, and sometimes you may have to solve a small puzzle to get stuff to absorb.

This game does have challenges though, you may have to avoid being hit by Army helicopters or tanks, or you may have to precariously avoid spikes, or you may sometimes have to outrun lasers, while performing other tasks, such as collecting objects to absorb or rotating something to pass.

Another mechanic are the powers, you can have Rocket Boosts, which offer air mobility, sometimes to collect out of reach items or escape a laser. You also have magnetism, which helps you attach to surfaces and avoid obstacles. Then you have telekenesis, which let's you open up paths, move objects, or launch yourself.

The music in this game kinda gave me a Rayman Origins feel at times, I have no idea why, but it was enjoyable to listen to. The graphics vary in style, one minute, you can go from an 80's/90's style to a pixellated style.

The game overall is kinda short, even if you try to get all the achievements and 100% the game. This game overall gets a 9/10, the only part that could be improved is making the game a bit longer.

Tales From Space : Mutant Blobs Attack est un chouette petit jeu qui propose une expérience courte, peu prise de tête, mais très sympa !

C'est une alternance (ou un mix) de plateforme et puzzle game où les défis sont rarement bien compliqués, mais suffisamment pour être agréables à résoudre. Niveau gameplay, c'est parfois un peu pataud (et notamment le contrôle des objets via stick droit ne répond pas toujours parfaitement), mais ça n'est que rarement une source d'échec frustrant, et comme les checkpoints sont réguliers, pas de quoi jeter son pad. 
Je regrette un peu que le principe d'avalage des objets soit si cadré dans des phases spécifiques, mais cela reste plaisant quand même. ("Ouh ! Mon blob a atteint les 15m de diamètre ? Neat !" :D)

Les graphismes sont super sympa, avec un style très cartoonesque dans l'esprit -à mon sens- des shows un peu loufoques de la fin des 90s de Cartoon Network ; la musique est également tout à fait dans cet esprit. L'humour est très présent, donnant d'autant plus de plaisir à évoluer dans les niveaux. :) 

Le jeu est court (il m'aura occupé deux soirées), ce qui n'est pas un souci en soit : il évite de tirer en longueur son concept et on en sort amusé et content.

18451384.review:
Before I played this game I had a bad feeling about it because it looked like a Gish ripoff. The fact that the main character is a blob is pretty much where the similarities end though. Gish has a more elegant design, you control a physical object in all ways possible, angular momentum, rigidness, roughness etc and the whole gameplay was around that. Here things are more traditional. The controls are similar to any platformer except your character is a soft body. But this is a good thing! It means this game is doing its own thing, and succeeding, in my opinion.

Mutant Blobs is a very casual game that presents just enough challenge so you don't get bored. And most of the level design tries to throw fun things at you, I like that. Stuff that doesn't really qualify as a platform challenge or a puzzle, but it's still pleasuresome to do, like run through corridor eating stuff or get sucked into a pipe and watching the blob flow (reminiscent of Sonic loops and tunnels).

I love how the game looks. The cutscenes are funny.

There is a gimmick where you grow as you play the game, but it's usually just cosmetic (hence the term gimmick).

Not much more to say. I had fun and it is very affordable. Recommended.

17929921.review:
Imagine que você é um bolha de gosma consciente. Você foi torturado por cientistas, que picaram você, deram choques em você, martelaram, esmagaram, queimaram e remontaram dezenas de vezes. Não apenas você. Mas sua espécie inteira. É lógico que chega uma hora que a vingança vai ter que acontecer.

É com essa premissa que Tales from Space Mutant Blobs Attack revive o climão de filme B dos anos 50 e coloca você no papel da bolha assassina em busca de vingança. Não com a crítica política embutida do clássico de 1958 ou os detalhes repulsivos da refilmagem de 1988, mas com um bom humor típico de Monstros vs Alienígenas.

Você começa o jogo fugindo do laboratório na mochila de um estudante em visitação para lá de desajeitado. A nossa querida bolha é minúscula, mas vai se expandindo na medida em que vai consumindo objetos e (mais tarde) pessoas e animais pelo seu caminho. Aliás, o processo de crescimento é fundamental para passar de determinadas fases e é a principal fonte de gargalhadas insanas quando o enredo atravessas os limites do absurdo em seus níveis finais.

O título combina momentos de plataforma, onde o pulo certo na hora certa é fundamental, com sequências que exigem mais massa cinzenta do que reflexos. As mecânicas do jogo parecem simples à princípio, mas logo vão se complicando e logo você estará precisando usar o mouse, diferentes teclas do teclado e velocidade para avançar. Ou xingando muito a pobre bolha mal-humorada na tela. Pelos níveis existem outras bolhas para serem libertadas e bolas de energia azul para coletar, mas nada disso importa para avançar a história, só tem sentido se você for um daqueles que precisam platinar o jogo ou que acham o nível de desafio normal fácil demais.

Esbanjando simpatia, o jogo ainda traz níveis extras que pegam carona na nostalgia e reproduzem jogos do passado, com uma jogabilidade mais fácil. Depois de níveis exaustivos de tentativa e erro, eles servem para aliviar a tensão e libertar o poder destruidor de sua bolha mutante. Afinal, você está aqui para isso mesmo: devorar tudo e todos como uma gigantesca ameba.

A trilha sonora é deliciosa e a direção de arte evoca o estilo dos anos 50, além de espalhar diversas piadas visuais pelo cenário, incluindo referências marotas a outros jogos.

Tales from Space Mutant Blobs Attack acaba sendo divertido como uma Sessão da Tarde nos bons tempos em que Sessão da Tarde era divertido.

Originalmente publicado em: http://blog.retinadesgastada.com.br/2015/09/jogando-tales-from-space-mutant-blobs.html

A cute, simple platformer that's enjoyable for all ages.  You are a blob who eats what is smaller than you.  As you eat you grow meaning that you eventually can eat just about everything you see.  The levels are well designed and the art style, music and sounds all work perfectly for a fun experience.  Expect a bit of a challenge if you plan to get all gold and unlock all achievements, but you won't pull your hair out.  The gameplay is simple, and slowly new additions to the gameplay are unveiled as you progress in the forgetful but entertaining storyline.  You will learn how to wall jump, how to use your telekinesis powers to move levers and slide platforms, and how to use magnets that attract and push you away.

Nothing hugely groundbreaking at all, but there's nothing wrong with taking a known to work recipe and splashing with a fresh coat of paint for you to enjoy.  Definitely recommend, especially if you are playing with kids.

Bu aralar içine girdiğim inceleme furyamı oyunların fiyatlarını dikkate alarak mı yapayım, yoksa bağımsız bir şekilde mi, bilemiyorum. Ne de olsa nereden olduğunu bilmediğim (muhtemelen Humble Bundle'dandır) bir şekilde kütüphanemde olan oyunlar oluyorlar.

Fiyata bakmazsam, eğlenceli (olduğunu tahmin ettiğim) bir telefon oyununun başarılı bir şekilde bilgisayara aktarılmasıyla karşı karşıyayız. Oyun 2-boyutlu platform türünde, Kendini çok ciddiye almıyor -ki ciddiye alınamayacak ürünlerde en sevdiğim özelliktir, cidden- böylece acayip diyarlarda yarı-zor platform numaralarıyla kendinizi eğlendiriyorsunuz. Mekanikler sıkmayacak kadar çeşitli, sürekli bir önceki andan farklı bir şey yapıyor oluyorsunuz. Tecrübemi özetlersem, hikayeyi (artık hikaye adına ne var denebilirse) pek de umursamadan, önümdeki numarayı çözmeye çalışıp -veya [i]her şeyi[/i] toplamaya çalışıp,- başaramayıp ölüp tekrar başlamak şeklinde. Çözmek demem sizi kandırmasın, bu bir bulmaca oyunu değil, aksiyoun oyunu. Çözmek, onu uygulamktan her zaman -çok daha- kolay oldu (en azından benim için, eğer platform oyunlarında iyiyseniz diğer türlü de olabilir.) Çözümü gördüğün ve uygulamasını da yapabileceğini bildiğin için tekrar başlamak çok can sıkıcı olmuyor. Harika bir oyun mu? Kesinlikle hayır! Ama oynadığın sürece eğlendirir mi? Muhtemelen.

Peki ya fiyata bakarsak? Eh, tabii ki kimsenin kişisel bütçesine karışmayacağım, ama bunun 1,5 katı fiyata, belki 5 (belki daha bile çok) kat uzun oynanış sunan [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/40800/]Super Meat Boy[/url]'u önerebilirim. O yüzden burada gördüğünüz çözümü "tamam ya er ya da geç yaparım" diye tekrar tekrar deniyorsunuz, SMB ise size "acaba bunu asla yapamayacak mıyım?" dedirtiyor (ama yeterince denemeden sonra onu da yapıyorsunuz) İşte o yüzden o yüzden bu oyunun sunduğu zorlukları aşınca "eh, iyi oldu, bir sonrakine geçelim" diyorsunuz, SMB'de ise ufak çaplı bir parti veriyorsunuz. Yani... demek istediğim, eğer bu oyunu Humble Bundle'dan almış olmasaydım şimdi pişman olmuştum, oysa SMB'e verdiğim paraya (kavga ve gürültüyle geçen zamanlardan sonra) "iyi bir alışveriş yapmışım" diye bakıyorum.

Default keybinds are a joke (literally unusuable) and there is no remapping support. The devs expect you to be able to use WASD, the mouse, and still reach the " key somehow. 

Game is unplayable as a result. 

(Note the number of bad reviews that complain about keybinds and remap issues. The remap problem also exists for left handed users, AZERTY keyboard users, and anyone who doesn't have a middle mouse button...among others)


EXPLANATION:
To do the "slam" move, you must push Middle Mouse OR the " key. My middle mouse is bound to alt+f4 (and I'm not changing my system settings for one game) so thats out. No problem, you think. I'll just use keyboard controls instead!

Except...on the keyboard slam is bound to " for some idiotic reason. Obviously your left hand on WASD moving can't reach this key so you think to yourself, "aha, the devs want me to use my right hand to push the slam key" (along with enter and right shift which both do other commands as well).  Sounds good right? Just play the game with both hands on the keyboard?

Except...you have to use the mouse to play. Its required.

As you get bigger, the world starts looking a little bit smaller and you go from absorbing crumbs to helicopters. The movement is wobbly but flowing and the puzzles aren't something you'll get stuck on.

The problem is that you've played this before. It's a physics-based, platform game with the odd puzzle thrown in for good measure. You start at one end of the level and you have to get to the other by unlocking doors/gates. You run, jump and use movement powers to get by. The fact you get bigger doesn't add much to the gameplay as you never 'feel' bigger as the levels zoom out and the blob's size seems to fluctuate between levels. For example, I spent most of the game going from 2m to 7m tall and back again until the last chapter where you sudden become 50m tall. 

So it's all been done before and the main gimmick of the game isn't enough for it to be all that fun. Not to mention that the game is extremely short as I managed to finish it in 2 hours (each level is about 5 minutes long). It willl be longer if you really want to collect all the blue circles and other blobs but it doesn't give you anything except the feeling of completeness I guess.

16249203.review:
[h1]A Paladin’s Steam Review: Tales from Space: Mutant Blob Attacks. You're a Big, Green and Growing Alien Blob. Yet You're Still Cute.[/h1]
[list]
[*]Genre: 2D Physics Platformer
[*]Developed & Published by: DrinkBox Studios
[*]Platform: Windows, Mac, Linux, PS3, Xbox 360 and PS Vita.
[*]Business Model: Base Game
[*][i]Copy Purchased by Myself[/i] 
[/list]
[b]Overall Gameplay Thoughts[/b]
Tales from Space: Mutant Blob Attacks is a side-scrolling 2D physics platformer where you take control of an ever-growing alien blob that consumes everything in its path. The main mechanic of Tales is the blob, which rolls around consuming objects and people in the level. This allows the blob to grow bigger and get past a series of obstacles on each level. It’s certainly a different mechanic from most platformers though I mostly have a neutral opinion on it. It works for this game. This is not a one-hit-die platformer so you can take multiple hits before popping. You’ll heal at checkpoints scattered about the level. The blob can also jump, smash to the ground as well as use telekinetic and magnetic powers to get around. All of which will be used to get past a series of increasingly-difficult series of obstacles. This helps keep the gameplay different each level. The main campaign is a decent feature of 24 fairly challenging levels. Every five or so levels are set in a differently themed area, featuring backgrounds with army bases, the moon and college dorm rooms. It’s cutesy and littered with references to other games, YouTubers and movies. The story itself is very limited, with some cutscenes only vaguely describing what’s going on. 

[b]The Platforming[/b]
It’s not my favorite kind of platforming. There’s a bit too much trial and error challenge for my liking as you try to get past obstacles using the game’s physics. I often found myself stuck in an area due to my own ineptitude and the game’s challenge. It doesn’t demand pixel-perfection such as the Giana Sisters but it does demand your attention. The twenty four levels almost outstay their welcome for me they do have a decent enough variety to keep them from being boring. I did find some of the telekinesis parts a bit overly frustrating though. However, the bonus levels that had you controlling the blob from a top-down perspective were pretty neat. 

[b]PC Settings[/b]
2D Platformers don’t need much to get by. But Mutant Blobs Attack has what it needs and then some. Music and Sound sliders are here. Controller vibration can be disabled. There’s a “CPU Performance” slider that goes low or high which will be useful for low-end rigs. A decent amount of resolution options, full screen and v-sync are here as well. Anti-Aliasing can be enabled/disabled. Otherwise, the game was very stable when I played it and I didn’t notice any issues. Music is a...weird quirky tune that fits in with the 50s aesthetic they went for. I’m not a fan of the 50s era aesthetic but it does work here. A controller is recommended for the best experience but keyboard and mouse is usable. 

[b]Final Thoughts[/b]
I personally didn’t enjoy my time with Tales from Space: Mutant Blob Attacks. This genre hasn’t been appealing to me much lately and Tales doesn’t change that. [u]But[/u], if you do like platformers, Mutant Blob Attacks is definitely worth getting. The platforming is very solid with plenty of variety for such a short title. Additionally, the charm it displays is hard to ignore. I’m not usually a fan of the 50s aesthetic but it works for this one. If you want something that’s cutesy yet still challenging, I don’t think you can go wrong with this game. 

[b][url=http://kingisaaclinksr.com/2015/06/07/a-paladins-steam-review-tales-from-space-mutant-blob-attacks-youre-a-big-green-and-growing-alien-blob-yet-youre-still-cute/]Read this and more on A Paladin Without A Crusade[/url][/b]

15130796.review:
If the title didn't really tell you, this game radiates charm in everything it does. Playing like a 2D Katamari, you journey as an adorably grim blob out to have revenge for its tortured blob comrades, and you do so in some gloriously well paced and charming ways. While there are puzzles to be found in this physics platformer, none pose more than a few minutes of challenge to figure them out, as the main draw is simple catharsis of consuming the planet. There is a bit of challenge to be found in the secondary task to find your friends (and eat them), but most can be found fairly easy and only occassionally serve any real challenge. Making this sound like a bad thing is rather foolish of me, as this game is meant to be enjoyed for what it is. Given how this is pre-Guacamelee Drinkbox, I loved seeing their roots and their love of reference-filled billboards clearly has been an ongoing gag of theirs. This game's main draw for the hardcore is speed and time attacks, but I was never really compelled to do so, as I had far too much fun seeing what weird things I got to eat next. Play this game for the experience and the charming cutscenes, but don't expect much else outside of the main storyline. It's worth the short playtime, I assure you.

(Note: I played this game while my power was out, so my play time is a bit inaccurate. I finished it in about 5 hours overall to give you an idea of how long it is.)

Overall is someone asked me to briefly tell them what I thought of Tales From Space: Mutant Blobs Attack, I'd say it made me smile, and I'd absolutely recommend

14212134.review:
A very pretty, polished arcade platform puzzler available for Windows, Mac & Linux, of the "absorb random stuff so you grow large enough to absorb yet more random stuff and escape to the next part of the level" genre.  Sounds simple enough, huh?  :)

Pros:
+ Graphics (looks and feels as beautiful as you might hope it could from the screen shots, even on a modest machine!)
+ The mechanics and physics (comfortable, intuitive and well behaved)
+ Gameplay (enough differences between the levels to keep you interested, stimulated and challenged.)
+ Difficulty (progresses in a friendly and carefully linear way: not too hard to upset a casual player, but a gamer who wants to get 100% will scratch their head until they hit that "Doh" moment when it all suddenly becomes obvious!)
+ Sound (great soundtrack, but see below.)
+ Multiplatform (Windows, Mac AND SteamOS/Linux comatible - I've mainly been playing under Linux.)

Cons:
- Very hard to find anything bad about it, but perhaps there's not quite enough variation in the soundtrack sometimes if you're playing a bit of an addicted marathon - however, it's such a minor point it's not worth fixating on.

In summary:  I have nearly a 100 games in my steam library, but I just can't stop playing this one; hence I felt compelled to write my first steam review.  I can often measure the amount by which I enjoy a game by whether or not I just want to get to the next level OR whether I'm enjoying this level so much that I'm determined to clear it to 100% -- a rarity for me (as I don't often trying to fully complete games) Mutant Blobs definitely fits into the later category.  :)  Although I bought this game in a bundle, I would actually have been happy to pay full price.

Definitely recommended! :)

14195328.review:
A fun little platforming katamari-esque game where you play as the Mutant Blob looking to get revenge on the humans of planet Earth by devouring everyone on it. Due to its simplicity, slight escalating challenge, cartoony appearance, and lovely jazz soundtrack, this game's a great relaxation game to turn to after any stressful period.

As far as complaints go, the "Blob gets larger" theme goes throughout the game, but only really escalates in the last and first chapter. Everywhere in between feels more like filler as the blob constantly shifts from a mid-large size to a huge one. As such until the first and last chapters there's never really a real feeling of size as everything adjusts itself to you, so it never quite reaches that katamari ideal. The telekenisis power is a fun addition, but a bit finicky and hard to control on circular objects. But otherwise the game works beautifully and is an enjoyable short game.

If you need a quick nice looking game, you've got your mysterious blob right here.

14106376.review:
[h1]AT A GLANCE[/h1]
(Full review follows below)

[list]
[*] [b]Game Name:[/b] Tales From Space: Mutant Blobs Attack
[*] [b]Original Release:[/b] 2012
[*] [b]Genre Tags:[/b] 2D; Side Scroller; Platformer; Action
[*] [b]My Overall Grade:[/b] A-
[*] [b]Estimated Playtime (Campaign):[/b] 3-7 hours
[*] [b]Multiplayer Aspect:[/b] None
[*] [b]Recommended To:[/b] Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Casual gamers
[/list]	

[h1]REVIEW[/h1]
[b]Mutant Blobs Attack[/b] is a fun little puzzle-platformer that’s very light in both the puzzle and platforming departments.  It boils down to a short-but-sweet casual experience that will entertain, slightly challenge, and not frustrate. 

The game is extremely light-hearted and is very casual.  The levels are pretty short and simple.  That being said, I really enjoyed the level design in this game: you have to pay attention but you don’t really have to [i]think[/i].  It’s a nice experience: it mildly challenges (mostly only if you’re going for the gold medals), has plenty of checkpoints, and there are no overly frustrating parts.  As someone who prefers casual games to frustrating ones; I can say I really enjoyed this.   If you are someone who enjoys punishment from their games, you may want to look elsewhere.

There is no real story or anything, but it doesn’t need a story.  There are a few catoon-esque cutscenes.  The cartoonish art style and the music are a perfect match to the gameplay.  The platforming was smooth for me; I used a controller and was never frustrated with controls/response.  It is a short game, and is pretty easy to 100%.  As you progress, there are a handful of platforming mechanics that are mixed around to keep thinks interesting.

To surmise: [b]Mutant Blobs Attack[/b] is a casual platformer with mild puzzle aspects and a cartoon finish.  A short-medium length game that is pretty easy, yet very entertaining.

13946847.review:
Tales From Space: Mutant Blobs Attack is a puzzle-action platformer. You are a "blob", an alien that has only one goal : eat everything through 24 levels (6 worlds) + 5 mini-games.

You can jump, fall onto the ground with strength to break things, use special power to get close or away to metal objects + move some specific objects. That is simple, but enough to give you tough challenges through some levels.
For each level, you can get a medal (silver or gold, depending on your score : the higher, the better) and you have to look for 2 Blob Friends (1 for the mini-games). Tip for level 16 : in order to get a gold medal, your score has to be at least 29000, which means that you have to eat almost everything available, pretty difficult !
There is a leaderboard, so, if you want to be the best among your friends or even around the world, it adds some replay value !

Overall, this game is pretty fun and 5-6 hours should be enough to get all of the achievements.

13873614.review:
First things first - this is a very fun and engaging little budget platformer, but I can't recommend it at it's base price. $8 for essentially a 3ish hour game simply isn't worth it unless it's a clear step above its competition and in a world where Super Meat Boy and Rayman Legends exist, this game doesn't cut it.

However, if you can grab this game on sale for about $4 or less, I fully recommend getting it.

+/- Graphics are standard 2D fare with nothing that will push even the lowliest of toasters. That said, the art design is great, creating a fun and interesting visual look that takes what could easily be a bland looking game and pushes it above other budget titles. The developers found the look that worked for them and took full advantage of it.

+/- Controls are fairly basic but control well. Rarely did I ever feel that I failed because the game didn't respond to my inputs correctly. Basic platforming is fun and responsive, but while the game adds some variety to basic gameplay, never really grows beyond its basic premise.

+/- Puzzles and minigames give you some breaks from traditional platforming. The minigames are well done, if way too easy, as they re-imagine the game as an 8 bit top down arcade game. Despite the great twist on visuals and gameplay, there literally is zero challege to them other than "how fast can you complete it" with no fail states. Puzzles are likewise fairly easy and quite repetitive, basically moving some platforms about to block/avoid lasers. While they are fun the first time, they quickly get tiresome.

TL:DR - a fun, if short platformer that isn't worth full price, but grab it when on sale if you like indie platformers with alot of charm.

13816692.review:
Don't let other reviews fool you, [b]Tales from Space: When Mutant Blobs Attacks[/b] bears only a superficial resemblance to [b]Katamari Damacy[/b]. Whereas the later could be described as the ultimate chill game full of wacky Japanese humor, this is more of a traditional puzzle-platformer based around using your weird mutant blob powers to avoid ever-present death. "Eating" is only present as a way to bypass roadblocks in your quest to get from point A to point B.

First of all, check the amount of time I've spent into this game and divide that by two: that's a good estimate on the amount of time you'll invest. I'm a completionist who spent way too much effort trying to complete some of the more frustrating jumps, hence why it's over five hours. Check with other reviewers if you don't believe me: [b]Tales from Space: When Mutant Blobs Attacks[/b] is quite short, undoubtedly the shortest game for me to complete in my library. Compounding this problem is how little there is for you to do: apart from the jumping around and a dive move, you only have [u]three[/u] gameplay mechanics. Shoulder buttons control the Magnetize and the Telekinesis powers, and on certain stages you gain rocket powers. The game is imaginative enough in finding enough challenges for these abilities but compared to other products from [b]Lunchbox Games[/b] (and particularly [b]Guacamelee[/b]), this seems incredibly limited.

Enjoyment of the actual product is a mixed bag. On one hand, I [i]really[/i] want to congratulate the person in charge of the physics engine. From the soft physics of your mutant blob to the inertia produced by your rocket travels to the orbiting of magnetic bodies, everything [i]feels[/i] great. If there's a failing, it'd be in the actual platforming. 97% of the time it works fine (if not a bit floaty); it's that last 3%, the jumps required for some of the hidden blob friends that are simply bullshit. It's so frustrating looking over the solution online, know what you have to do, then fail repeatedly because the theory doesn't follow practice. I'm not going to downvote a game for a couple of bullshit jumps but it needs to be said that some platforming depends on ridiculous edge-of-platform running jumps that simply don't work, or a "magnetized-bouncy-super-high-jump" technique... Yeah, this review doesn't make it easy for the prospective buyer to understand so let's just leave it at "bullshit jumps".

This game is both easier and more frustrating than [b]Guacamelee[/b]. Those who've played the lucha libre Metroidvania will get to reexperience the furious shoulder button pressing extravaganza needed to bypass treacherous areas all over again. Puzzle-wise you have your blob use its telekinesis powers to move platforms around, the solution to which shouldn't take more than a few minutes to discover. There's very little replay value because the game offers so very little in the first place: [b]Tales from Space: When Mutant Blobs Attacks[/b] has the least amount of Achievements in my library and only offers a leaderboard in terms of additional content.

I never paid any monies for this product, having won it off the Steam winter auction at a little over 1000 gems. I'd say its value comes more as an interesting physics engine for a blobby protagonist than as a puzzle-platformer anyways. Don't pay more than five dollars for it and you shouldn't regret anything. It's not [i]bad[/i] or anything, just unsatisfying. You could say that it still left me hungry.

13709135.review:
[i]Tales From Space: Mutant Blobs Attack[/i] is a charming combination of side-scroller and platformer that balances out its lack in difficulty and very short length with its humor, appealing story and fluid gameplay.

In [i]Mutant Blobs Attack[/i], the player controls a single blob, escaped from a flask, bent upon conquest by consuming all in its wake. The blob utilizes all that it is capable of, including its platforming skills and low viscosity in order to maneuver through various areas of different shapes and sizes. It even later uses magnetism and telekinesis to manipulate terrain. The game provides over twenty-five levels spread through six areas to play through. (This level count includes a number of minigame levels, which are notably shorter than main levels.)

The game is satisfying to play. Despite the fact that the blob never talks or expresses thought, players will still connect to the amorphous creature - its progressive growth, guided by the player, makes the player feel somewhat like a parent to the creature. Further satisfaction comes from being able to easily devour objects which were insurmountable in earlier worlds. Bright colors and a bouncy soundtrack layer the game into being a cartoon-like experience. This shouldn't be conveyed as a turn-off to older or more mature gamers; rather, it should simply mean that the game is lighthearted.

Gameplay functionality varies between game modes. The majority of levels, the side-scrolling platformer sections, are effective. Controls are tight and responsive, leaving the majority of blame for damage on the player. Wall-jump mechanics are a noted exception, though this does not hinder core gameplay much. Airborne sections of the game are less effective. The propulsion systems on the character are too imprecise for slight movement, which when combined with obstacles that require finesse to maneuver around leads to frustrating experiences in this mode. The third game mode, the top-down mode, functions well, and its visual differentiation from the rest of the game just makes these sections even more pleasing than they already are.

For how much fun this game is, it will not last. The whole game can be completed in around three hours. Additionally, the game is quite easy throughout. For the few sections which provide ample difficulty, players will receive a notification from the game with a tip - even further simplifying the game, despite being a useful mechanic. The single-player campaign is the only mode in the game - having some sort of multiplayer mode, whether that be in the form of competitive races, a vs. mode, or co-op levels, would have increased the longetivity of the game significantly. Some replayability comes from retrying the levels to earn gold medals or find the two blob friends that are hidden in each area, but with only 24 levels the experience could become monotonous for some players. With such an easy difficulty and a cartoony interface, younger players may find the best experience with this game.

[i]Mutant Blobs Attack[/i] is a great game that's been reduced to a good game. With such little material contained in the game itself, gamers should consider whether their money is spent better with a lengthier experience. For what this does contain, though, it is a gratifying adventure that will stroke the supervillain in players and will entertain throughout its duration. [i]Tales From Space: Mutant Blobs Attack[/i] gets a C+.

13456382.review:
Das Konzept von "Tales From Space: Mutant Blobs Attack" ist einfach: Iss, werde größer. Das Spiel nimmt dabei Bezug auf einen beliebten Topos aus der goldenen Ära der B-Movies. Nette Idee. Leider ist die einzig wirkliche Herausforderung in diesem Spiel, die Steuerung zu beherrschen. Schon früh werden allerhand Funktionen eingeführt, mit denen man schwachsinnige Rätsel lösen soll. In jedem Level gibt es zwei "versteckte" Freunde, die Bonuspunkte geben und selbst diese sind derart leicht zu finden, dass man meist schon nach dem ersten Durchlauf beide gefunden hat. 
Der wohl größte Griff ins Klo ist die Linearität. Gerade das Konzept "Iss, werde größer" läd doch dazu ein, dem Spieler ein offen gehaltenes Level zu servieren, indem er sich von kleinen essbaren Gegenständen, zu größeren hocharbeiten kann! (Ein gutes Beispiel wäre hier "The wonderful end of the world", auch wenn es sich hierbei um ein eher mittelmäßiges, kurzweiliges, aber durchaus spaßiges Spiel handelt.) Stattdessen wird man an der Hand genommen und meist, buchstäblich, durch einen schmalen Tunnel ohne Abzweigung gequetscht. Korken verhindern, dass man weiter im Level fortschreitet ohne eine gewisse Größe erlangt zu haben, die sich jedoch scheinbar völlig willkürlich zu Beginn eines neuen Levels ändert. Das irritiert mich. Wozu dann überhaupt nach allen essbaren Gegenständen suchen? Für die Punkte? Wen interessieren die scheiß Punkte?
"Tales From Space: Mutant Blobs Attack" ist sicher nicht das schlechteste Spiel der Welt und ich kann mir vorstellen, dass es eine Menge Leute mögen. Das ist ok. Denen werde ich keine Geschmacksverirrung attestieren. Mir jedoch gefällt es einfach nicht.
Ein schöne Alternative mit ähnlichem Spielkonzept bietet übrigens "The Maw"

13405188.review:
Povedená plošinovka s malým, větším.. až největším blobem. 

Kdesi v laboratoři utekl malinký Blob. Jeho cíl je jasný - absorbovat do sebe cokoli co je menší, než on. A to co je větší zbaští až trošku přibere. Za cca 6 herních hodin toho Blob zbaští opravdu hodně. Ale protože jde o hru od kanadských DrinkBox Studios (Guacamelee), nebude to mít Blob/hráč vždycky úplně jednoduché. Čas od času si nad některou pasáží asi pěkně zanadáváte... ale to je nakonec celkem dobře, alespoň se pak hra líp pamatuje.:-) 

Blob totiž naštěstí nemusí řešit jenom to, jestli už je větší než ta krabice, či kráva, aby jí mohl sníst. Do cesty se mu staví i lasery, bodce, rotující mechanismy a bůhvíjaké další nebezpečnosti. Hra využívá konceptu na maximum a řekl bych, že k řešení problémů obvykle vede nějaká nová, nebo alespoň lehce obměněná cesta. Milý Blob totiž neumí jenom tupě hopsat - může se i přitahovat na magnetické předměty a občas i létat. Radost by z toho ovšem mít neměl, protože to autorům umožňuje stavět mu do cesty další a další pasti.   

TFS:MBA (=príma zkratka názvu) se do určité míry podobá Guacamelee. Především vizuálním stylem a hudebním doprovodem. Čas od času i obtížností. Ale celkově je asi o něco lehčí (pozor, skoro cokoli je lehčí, než Guacamelee:-) a rozmanitější. Mezi skákačkami patří určitě k těm lepším.

Za kolik stojí: < 3€

13173544.review:
Though this wasn't a bad game, it was definitely disappointing.  I liked the level of creativity involved, but my main gripe with the game is it is very short and overall pretty easy.  There are some frustratingly difficult parts while the rest of it is a breeze.  But, there are always ways to further challenge yourself if you want to.

The blob you play as is a little too conveniently powerful.  There should be penalties to some things you eat, and your special abilities should occur due to things you eat.  Instead, you just always have them.  The only incentive to eat in this game is to become bigger and for score, otherwise, there's no point.

The artistic style and music is definitely interesting, but I wish there were more songs.  The way the game scales everything as you get bigger is a nice touch, but you are considerably downsized every time you start a new level.  Kind of makes you feel like you aren't actually making progress.  Then you get exponentially bigger toward the end, as though the devs felt they ran out of time.

Don't get me wrong, this game is worth playing, but it isn't as special as it could've been.  If you like games with blobs, I'd recommend Gish over this.

It's an entertaining platformer game, but IMHO not much more than that. The plot is as simple as the mechanics: absorb everything! From pretty much the beginning, you are on a constant quest for things smaller than you so you can grow. You start out eating paper clips and hamburgers and end up with tanks and even larger things (no, I won't spoil it). It's basic fun, really. Especially when humans start noticing you and try to stop you.

Still...though it has some not-too-easy segments, the overall isn't very challenging. Aside from the basic search-and-absorb and a slam down attack (if you want to call it that), you have magnetic powers that attract or retract you. It has some moments (think Mario Galaxy), but IMHO not really enough to carry the entire game. I played through it in 3.5 hours and kept playing mostly for the (hilarious) cutscenes, the billboards with winks to other games and the music (which is great).

Overall...I'd say it's about 7 out of 10. It probably doesn't help that I've played this after Guacamelee gold (which is Drinkbox's later game), which has stuff that I found missing here (like a boss fight here and there...and more a sense of growth in abilities). Still...I'd thumbs up this. :-)

덩어리를 굴려 물건들 접착시키고 덩어리 키워나가는 괴혼이란 게임을 플래포머 게임으로 바꿔놓으면 딱 이 게임이 된다.

게임이 쉬워서 좋다. 맵 길이도 적절하고. 그냥 깨긴 참 쉽고, 금메달이랑 숨겨진 뮤턴트 친구들 찾아가면서 플레이할 때도 별도의 공략 없이 조금만 노력한다면 스스로 충족할 정도의 난이도이다. 실제로 스팀 가이드에 공략이 없어서 걱정을 조금 했었는데, 기우였다.

게임이 짧아서 좋다. 총 24개의 스테이지, 5개의 미니게임. 원래 PSN용으로 나왔던 게임이었고, 괴혼을 보는 듯한 전체적인 줄거리의 흐름도 재밌었다. 짧고 깔끔하게 즐기기 딱 좋은 게임. 로켓버드처럼 코옵을 지원해줬더라면 더 재밌었을 것 같긴 한데, 없어도 딱히 크게 아쉽진 않다.

게임에 패러디가 많은 것도 좋았다. 배경의 전광판에는 어지간한 인디 게임들을 웃기게도 잘 패러디해놨고, 틈틈히 다른 인디 게임의 컨셉(ex: 레트로 시티 램페이지)을 가져온듯한 스테이지도 볼만했다. 아는 인디 게임이 많다면 더 재밌게 볼 수 있을 부분들.

오랜만에 괴혼 생각도 난 것도 있고, 어찌저찌 정신없이 즐겼던 게임.

(그러고보면 PS 쪽으로 이런 인디 게임들이 잘 나온다. 로샤드도 그랬고, 로켓버드도 그랬고... 확실히 엑박보단 플스 쪽이 인디 씬에 해주는 대우가 더 좋은 모양인가보다.)

Absolutely, positively, hands-down one of the "funnest" (and funniest) games ever made.  

   You play a blob who graduates from being a mere splotch on a university campus to a monster big enough to eat the entire SOLAR SYSTEM!  It's as simultaneously silly and genius as it sounds, and clever enough in its design that even an eejit of such limited hand-eye coordination and puzzle-solving skills as myself could get through it...though some serious perseverance was required in a few bits, let me tell ya!  

   About the only remotely constructive criticism I can manage is that a few such insanely-difficult sections could perhaps use an extra checkpoint or two in their midst. But all those clever clogs who think they're the bees-fuckin'-knees at these games are gonna see this level of difficulty as a plus and not a minus anyway, so it's barely worth mentioning.  

   One of those rare games you can safely recommend to just about "everyone", or at least anyone with even a whiff of open-mindedness and a vague sense of humour.  HIGHLY FUCKING RECOMMENDED.  And a steal even at full price!!!
 
Verdict: 9.5/10.

Avis plutôt mitigé sur le jeu. Sur les 6 mondes que compte le jeu, on ne sent une progression que lors des deux premiers. Passé ce cap, énormément de recyclage, plus du tout d'innovation de gameplay, et surtout une grande lassitude. De surcroit, il y a un recyclage continuel des mêmes assets graphiques du jeu.

Le problème est que passé ce monde 2, le concept du blob dévoreur est flingué par les développeurs. En effet, le blob, qui était censé grandir tout au long du jeu, est systématiquement rétréci à une taille humaine au début de chaque niveau, et ce, jusqu'à l'avant-dernier niveau et le dernier niveau ou là il prend enfin vraiment de la taille!!!

Dans ce style, "The Maw" faisait beaucoup mieux car l'augmentation de la taille du blob était constante au fur et à mesure des niveaux! Malgré tout celà, le jeu est sympathique à jouer, on passe un bon moment avec ce héros de série Z visqueux!

11545609.review:
Mutant Blobs - Gotta Eat Them All!
Очень качественный и веселый платформер от DrinkBox Studios, более известных благодаря другой игре - Guacamelee.
Мы играем за крутого блоба, существа, похожего на слайма или некий шарик желе. Нашему ГГ надоело, что его и других блобов люди держат в клетках и проводят над ними различные эксперименты, обрекая их на мучительную смерть. Наш блоб устраивает побег из лаборатории, освобождает своих друзей и начинает реализовывать свой план мести людям. 
Вот тут мы и подходим к геймплейной составляющей: основная задача на всех уровнях - съесть как можно больше вещей, чтобы расти и продвигаться через ранее непроходимые места. Если сначала наш блоб очень маленький и легко прячется в обычном рюкзаке, то к концу игры он будет огромным монстром, поедающим людей, танки, города... и даже больше =) Помимо способности к поеданию всего подряд, наш персонаж имеет еще некоторые навыки: притягивание и отталкивание своего тела к металлическим объектам, разгон и полет на реактивной тяге (и черт возьми, это реально похоже на полет баттхертщика на тяге своей пятой точки, уж простите :D).
Что касается всего остального, то здесь тоже все нормально - приятная 2D графика и неплохая музыка (хоть и повторяющаяся в разных уровнях). Чувство юмора у авторов тоже присутствует - тут есть куча различных отсылок к другим играм и мемам, которые часто вызывают улыбку =)
Эту игру я могу посоветовать всем, кто хочет погонять в приятную и веселую игру, без особых напрягов в геймплейном плане. Тем, кому понравился Guacamelee - игра обязательна к ознакомлению. 7,5/10

10789959.review:
Tales From Space: Mutant Blobs Attack is a 2D side-scrolling puzzle-platform game that heirs the concept of Katamari franchise: eat, get big, continue. The game is really simple and short. But that is not a problem. The gameplay time seems right, it took me around 4 hours long, and I had no difficulties so far. The story? Well, not a big story to get in love. Just the basic to get you flowing and eating everything. One of the biggest qualities of this game is the humour. Seriously, the game is packed with humorous references to other indie games and to the entertainment world as a whole. The music is ok. The controls are sharp. It feels good to play on a controller, but you can beat it on a keyboard as well. 

Tales From Space: Mutant Blobs Attack has its flaws but it's worthy playing it. Try it when you just want a humorous game that will let you relax from a hard day. 

Score: 7.8 out of 10.

9003837.review:
総合評価　７．５／１０

良い所
　思わず笑ってしまう下らなさ。
　カジュアルだがそれなりに遊べる難易度。
　作風にマッチしたポップなビジュアル。
　単純だが、ゲームプレイに刺激を与えてくれるギミックやプレイメカニック。

悪い所
　RSのメカニックに遊びが無いようで暴発する。
　時としてシビアでイライラさせられる難易度。
　一部わかりにくい攻略メカニック。
　ブロブがステージ毎に大きくなっていることがわかりづらい。
　（画面に対するブロブの比率がいつも同じくらいだから）

物語の説明などの文章やセリフなどは無いので、日本語はないがプレイメカニックを理解できれば問題ない。
ただ、一部攻略する際のメカニックなどで、たまに出てくるチュートリアルやヒントなどは訳せたほうが良い。
カジュアルゲームなので細かい調整などは全くなされていないが、その分細かいことを気にせず気軽に楽しめる。
基本的にはジャンプアクションで、ゲームが進むと新たな能力が使えるようになる。
それらの能力も使い所が決まっているため迷うことはない。
また、ブロブが吸収できる物を次々と飲み込むことによって、次のステージへ進めるような作りであり、飲み込んだものがスコアとなって最終的な評価へと繋がる為、そういったプレイが自然とできるように工夫されている。
難易度の高いゲームの合間などに息抜き程度に遊ぶと更に楽しめる。

8977576.review:
I wasn't entirely sure what to expect from 'Tales From Space: Mutant Blobs Attack' when it was first recommended to me. All I was told was 'it's a short 3-4 hour game, just sit back, play it and tell me what you think'. So here is what I think!

It IS a short 3-4 hour game, and I'm fine with that as it's the perfect length and really helps keep the game's charm alive. What this game is is a fun platform/puzzle game that has more internet references and meta-memes than 4chan and Reddit. It's pleasing art style and audio presentation only help maintain the charm that this game has. I realise I've mentioned the word 'Charm' twice within the same paragraph, and I guess that's the overal feeling towards this game. It's charming.

It manages to hook it's way into you and before you know you've finished the game, laughed at the various Pop/Cult References you've seen and come away feeling like you need to tell other people to 'just sit back, play it and tell me what you think'.

8044775.review:
Tales From Space: Mutant Blobs Attack (or TFS: MBA, as all the cool kids call it) is a pretty straightforward game. You control a blob, I don't think he, she or it is given a name at any point, but for the purposes of this review I shall call him Steve... Steve DeBlob. Though as far as I know he isn't any relation to the blob from De Blob, that platforming, paint-'em-up classic, though I could be wrong. Instead, Steve DeBlob is a translucent, green blob with one eye who rolls through various 2D environments overcoming obstacles and gathering up ever bigger items to increase his size as he exacts his revenge against his human captors, and ultimately humanity as a whole. Sort of like a cross between Katamari Damacy, the underrated Puddle and that movie where the guy goes mental and kills everybody... you know the one I mean, right?

Both the platforming and puzzles are fairly easy affairs to begin with, maybe even a little tedious in their initial simplicity, but the difficulty level is judged almost perfectly as it ramps up at a steady and satisfying pace over the twenty-four levels. New elements of gameplay are gradually added to the mix, like the ability to move select platforms around with the cursor or being able to attract and repel Mr. DeBlob from certain structures, which nicely expands the range and complexity of puzzles that are thrown at you. But still, with little punishment for failure and a very forgiving checkpoint system, the majority of players won't be massively challenged for the most part, except maybe if you're a completionist intent on collecting everything, unlocking achievements or troubling the leaderboards, and depending on which of these players you are you'll likely make your way to the end in about four to six hours.

Bonus kudos has to go to the end game, though. Most of the time your reward for completing a game will be a fancy cutscene wrapping up the story, but here it's done a little differently. There are six chapters to tackle, with the first five incrementally increasing in difficulty, but by the sixth it shifts gears and becomes much easier while focusing everything on a different aspect rather than challenge... FUN. By the beginning of chapter six you've more or less beaten the game since you've made your way through the hardest parts and have essentially become a badass that can just stomp and roll your way through the stages with relatively little effort. So instead of having to endure one final, ultimate obstacle to prove your mastery of the game, your reward in place of a cutscene is to enjoy your power as you decimate everything in your path. It's a great way to end your time with any title and I really wish more games would follow this design, especially with the very last stage being a particularly great pay-off for all your work, and with the cherry on top being the sweet asking price, there's little excuse to not go and make friends with Steve DeBlob right now.

7793136.review:
Una storia di vendetta e ribellione, di guerra e rinascita, di rivoluzione. Il nostro bel Blobbolo verde riesce a liberarsi dopo aver subito esperimenti e maltrattamenti multipli: cosa aspettarsi allora dopo un trattamento simile? La distruzione totale (direi…). Così inizia la nostra avventura come singola pallina di qualche centimetro, un’avventura che ci farà viaggiare dal microcosmo di vermi e ingranaggi al macrocosmo di… beh se ve lo dicessi vi rovinerei la sorpresa. Sta di fatto che durante gli esperimenti subiti, il nostro Blobbolo ha ottenuto una serie di abilità uniche che ci aiuteranno a risolvere i singoli quadri di questo platform/puzzle piuttosto interessante. Potremo, infatti, sfruttare gli oggetti metallici col fenomeno del magnetismo (respingere o attrarre), fagocitare qualsiasi cosa (inanimata o animata) per aumentare le nostre dimensioni e procedere nel livello, ma soprattutto utilizzare per alcuni momenti un sistema a reazione che permetterà una maggiore e migliore esplorazione del livello.

Vieni a leggere la recensione completa su TheShelterNetwork.com:
http://theshelternetwork.com/mutant-blobs-attack/

"Quatre heures de jeu pour le finir une fois, deux petites heures de plus pour trouver tous les Blobs cachés dans les niveaux et obtenir un maximum de bons scores, voilà ce qui vous attend. Et surtout, c’est très facile. Il y a des checkpoints partout, au début de chaque passage un peu compliqué, ce qui empêche toute frustration et donc, toute pression. C’est réellement dommage, mais en soi, cela ajoute aussi un potentiel “très grand public” assez sympathique. Cela reste un réel problème, mais beaucoup feront avec. 

Surtout qu’on ne s’en lasse pas une seule seconde, que le level design est réellement inventif (à défaut d’être complexe, donc). Cet ersatz de Katamari Damacy en 2D propose de réels grands moments de fun : passer d’une simple chambre au cosmos en moins d’une trentaine de niveaux est jouissif, surtout lorsqu’on nous propose de revenir sur nos pas pour dévorer ce qui nous faisait obstacle auparavant. 7569129.review:
Tales from Space: Mutant Blobs Attack is a side-scrolling puzzle platformer about a mutant blob that can consume anything that is smaller than itself, yet grows every time it consumes something. I think you know where this is headed... 

For starters, Mutant Blobs Attack is very well designed. The art style is truly awesome, a cartoony world in a 1950's horror movie setting, most likely with a wink to Steve McQueen's (hilarious) The Blob. Combined with small cutscenes in a similar style, this side of the game is genuinely funny. The soundtrack is catchy and fits well with the chosen aesthetics. 

The level design is excellent, its never too hard to figure out where to go next. With 24 levels in 6 zones the game provides plenty of variation, with an enjoyable mini game in each of these zones. The puzzles are no brain teasers but do provide a nice shift from otherwise continuous platforming. The gameplay in general is fairly straightforward, but every level has another approach or gimmick that took away every sense of repetitiveness. 

While in general Mutant Blobs Attack is not very challenging, once you go for the gold medals and finding every secret there's a whole new level of difficulty for those seeking a challenge. The checkpoint system is rather brilliant, avoiding that even the harder parts of the game become frustrating. The controls are decent, with the exception to wall-jumping, which is a little dodgy. 

Concluding, Mutant Blobs Attack is a truly funny game that excels to great heights if/when you also decide to challenge yourself. It's not perfect, but its definitely one of the best platformers I've ever played. And for its price, you really should not ignore it. 

+ Hilarious visual presentation
+ Fitting soundtrack
+ Challenging if you let it be
+ Smart checkpoint system
+ Never becomes too repetitive 

- Dodgy walljumping mechanics
- A wee bit on the short side


8.5/10

3452523.review:
Ditching the recent mindset that platformers for some reason need to be mercilessly difficult, Drinkbox Studios instead pours their heart and soul into the area I feel matters most in a game, that unquantifiable "fun factor", and it shows in every inch of Mutant Blobs Attack.

The comical and cartoony presentation is no doubt its biggest asset, creating a game that is both delightful to hear and behold, as well as one that somehow turns the act of mass murder into a lighthearted affair. It also packs in more indie game references than possibly any before it, which had me grinning the whole way through as I saw my favorites reimagined in very amusing ways. What's more, none of this comes at the cost of great levels or mechanics. Although it shows obvious influence from games such as The Maw and Katamari, Mutant Blobs carves out its own niche in the platforming genre with consistently clever design that feels wholly unique. Again and again it defied my expectations which is by no means something I say often.

Other than a handful of times I had to wrestle with the controls, there is virtually nothing I dislike about Mutant Blobs Attack. It's hilarious, polished, and most of all a ton of fun. Some might find the 3-4 hour length a little unfulfilling, but to me this is something of a compliment in and of itself, as the only reason I want more is because what is here is just that good!

3175323.review: Tales From Space: Mutant Blobs Attack is one of the most fun platformers I have played in a while. It has great control fun puzzles and you eat things to solve them. Originally released for the Play Station Vita TFS:MBA is a 2D platformer where you are an escaped blob and you eat things to solve puzzles and progress. As you eat you become larger and as a result you can eat larger things. The game also has a magnet system where certain metal objects can be attracted to, repelled from or moved. This system makes for some fun puzzles and in some situations fast reactions. There is also sections where you gain the ability to propel yourself through the air like you have a jetpack. These sections are fun and break up the game play nicely. The settings in the game are top notch and have you going to a variety of places like college and the moon. The humor is superb throughout the game. It is shown through billboard that parody other games and internet memes. If you see this go on sale get it, it’s worth your time and money and the last levels are very satisfying.

3609397.review:
Świetna platformówka traktująca o prawach zwierząt (istot... "żywych"?) i zemście na plugawej ludzkości. No dobra, przesadziłem - po prostu pochłaniasz wszystko na swojej drodze, od śrubek przez pizzę, ludzi, czołgi, na wieżowcach (nie)skończywszy. Główny bohater - zielony naburmuszony glut (będący prawdopodobnie dalekim kuzynem Gisha) wyrusza w podróż, po drodze znajdując swoich towarzyszy, z którymi nie przeżyje emocjonujących przygód, gdyż ich po prostu pożera. Całość stylizowana jest na retrofuturyzm rodem z amerykańskich lat 50. ubiegłego wieku - nawet jak ktoś nie jest fanem tych klimatów, nie powinien narzekać. 
Ponadto, po levelach poukrywanych jest pełno smaczków - głównie w postaci billboardów reklamowych przedstawiające m.in. produkty spożywcze, które nawiązują do gier indie (i nie tylko). Masz ochotę na orzeszki? Zjedz Awesomenuts. Wanna go into spaaaaaaaaace? Apertour Travel. Głodny? They feed pixels. Wyśmienity pomysł - i zabawne, i ładne, i promuje ciekawe niezależne gry.
Największy minus tej gry to pewne aspekty sterwania - gra jakby idealnie pasująca do pada, ale twórcy musieli napsuć, dodając fragmenty, gdzie wymagana jest obsługa myszki do "precyzyjnego" sterowania niektórymi elementami za pomocą telekinezy.. Nawet x-klockowy pad nie pomoże - czasem trzeba oderwać łapkę od kontrolera i machać gryzoniem. Zamiast tego wystarczyło by obłożyć drugą gałkę i jeden z przycisków. Na szczęście w takich momentach ( bez jednego razu zawsze) glut może stać w miejscu, więc nie trzeba multitaskować jednocześnie myszą i padem.
Ogólnie: jakieś 7 godzin ciekawej rozgrywki.
Gra zapadnie mi w pamięć jeszcze z jednego powodu - na kilka minut przed przejściem jej na 100% ducha wyzionął mój stary, wysłużony pad. Reanimacja w postaci macgyverowego lutowania (zapalniczka + plastikowe zatyczki od długopisów ftw) tymczasowo podtrzymują go przy życiu, jednak czuję, że na dniach czeka mnie wizyta w sklepie z pięknymi bezprzewodowymi kontrolerami...

5119102.review:
The story of [b]Tales From Space: Mutant Blobs Attack[/b] is pretty simple: You play as a blob breaking out of a blob torture research center and getting his revenge. On his way to do so the blob automatically absorbs everything that is smaller than him and so he is getting larger and larger and is able to absorb even more.

Over the course of the game you gain new abilities like smashing, telekinesis, magnetism and sometimes you can even fly around. Combined with the six different themed world stages and the never stopping growth of your blob the game never gets to repetitive besides it simple basic gameplay idea. The puzzles in the game are fairly easy what I did not really mind. The platformer part on the other hand is a bit tougher mainly for one reason. Besides the blob being a blob, and therefore precise movement can be a bit tricky, the controls are unusual. I have read some complains about them, because the game contains parts where you have to use the mouse. People playing the game solely on keyboard or gamepad have to shift over what can be annoying (Edit: This has been changed since the initial released and the game is playable with gamepad only by now). Personally I played the game one hand on the keyboard and the other one on the mouse. This combinations works pretty well. And even if you die you will start by one of the nearby checkpoints. Normally you should pass each passage with less than five times dying except you are trying to get the gold medals or you are collecting your blob friends.
Those unusual controls are a left over from the porting because the game was made initially for the PS Vita. Another leftover are the mini-levels which are a lot easier in the PC version but still fun. The graphic is cartoon-like and colourful and fits the theme of the game. The music is nothing special. It does not really stand out but it does not annoy you as well. The game took me eight hours for completion of all achievements and replaying some of the levels for getting better times in the leaderboards. And for that the price tag is really fair.

All in all [b]Tales From Space: Mutant Blobs Attack[/b] is a really, really fun and colourful game if you can forgive some sometimes clunky controls and you do not mind the repetitiveness of the basic gameplay idea. Obliteration of mankind can be so enjoyable.

811494.review:
Excellent Katamari-like 2D platformer with some light puzzling elements. The goal is to grow your blob to epic proportions by rolling over objects, vehicles and yes, humans. There are 2 fellow blobs hidden around the levels and every now and then you'll unlock a bonus level. The graphics are amazing, they're really stylish. I simply love them. I like how the levels have you starting off as a small blob (so everything around you appears big) and every new level you unlock shows the world getting smaller (ie, you appear bigger). Airplanes, for example, look like toys later on.
'So, iIs this the best thing ever ?', I hear you ask. No, unfortunately the controls are awkward at times. You basically use the keyboard for all your movements, but every now and then you have to use the mouse too, to slam through objects and things like that. It works, but not in a good way. It's about the only complaint I can think of.
It's a fun game that comes highly recommended !

[Rating: 87/100]
